page.title: 07The Oxford Canal-Kirtlington
page.content: The Oxford Canal was one of many engineered by James Brindley. It was built to link the River Thames at Oxford to the Grand Union Canal. There are 39 locks between Oxford and Braunston, the nearest to Kirtlington being Pigeon Lock. Pigeon Lock was built in 1788. The canal builders reached Northbrook on 13th August 1787. They finally reached Oxford on 1st January 1790. The canal used to be used mostly to transport freight but now it is used mainly for pleasure purposes such as fishing and holidays. We believe that there is still a coal merchant who travels the canal. The bank has recently been reinforced with metal corrugating. To find out more information either write to: Information Centre, British Waterways Board, Melbury House, Melbury Terrace, LONDON NW1 6JX, or tel: 01 262 6711.
